data.source: European Social Survey (ESS), rounds covering 2002–2009 (multiple rounds / waves)
data.wave_or_subset: ESS rounds 1–4 (2002–2009); analysis uses country-rounds and country-level aggregates (three-level structure: individuals, country-rounds, countries).
data.sample_size: 110,732 individual-level observations (reported for multilevel analysis); initial sample described as ~120,080 with exclusions (e.g., non-citizens) leading to the analytic sample reported as 110,732.
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual respondents (with higher-level units: country-round and country).
data.notes: Analysis excludes some respondents (e.g., non-citizens); macro-level variables constructed (e.g., far-right party vote share, social protection expenditure, GDP per capita, unemployment, governance quality). Key indexes: concern about immigration index (Cronbach's alpha = 0.83); economic dissatisfaction and governance indexes with reported inter-item correlations and Cronbach's alphas. Three-level data structure: Level 1 n≈110,732, Level 2 n=59 country-rounds, Level 3 n=16 countries.

method.description: The study uses multilevel (hierarchical) linear modeling to assess the relationship between concern about immigration and political distrust across European countries, controlling for individual-level covariates (demographics, economic satisfaction, interpersonal trust, political orientation), country-round level variables (far-right party popularity), and country-level variables (historical immigration status, governance quality, macroeconomic conditions). Robustness checks include instrumental-variables analyses using the first ESS round and interaction tests (e.g., between immigration concern and long-term immigration history or far-right presence).
steps: Obtain ESS survey data for rounds covering 2002–2009.
Select analytic sample (exclude specified respondents such as non-citizens as done in the paper).

Construct individual-level variables and indexes: concern about immigration index (validated, Cronbach's alpha reported), political distrust measures (parliament, politicians, legal system), economic dissatisfaction index (reverse-coded satisfaction items), social capital measures, demographic controls (age, education, gender, income, left-right placement), and indicators for voting behavior (e.g., voted for far-right).

Assemble country-round and country-level variables: far-right party vote share/popularity, social protection expenditure, GDP per capita, unemployment rates, governance quality index (from World Bank indicators), and dummy coding for long-term vs. recent immigration countries.

Estimate three-level hierarchical linear models (individuals nested in country-rounds nested in countries) predicting political distrust, including main effects and interactions (e.g., immigration concern × long-term immigration country; immigration concern × far-right popularity).

Report coefficients, statistical significance, and variance explained at each level; perform robustness checks, including instrumental-variables analysis using ESS round 1 and alternative model specifications.
Interpret results, focusing on the size and significance of immigration concern, interactions with historical immigration status and far-right presence, and the role of control variables.
method.models: Three-level hierarchical linear models (multilevel linear regression / HLM). Additional instrumental-variables analysis for endogeneity checks. Interaction models between individual concern about immigration and country-level moderators (long-term immigration status, far-right party popularity).
method.outcome_variable: Political distrust toward national political institutions and actors (measures include distrust of parliament, politicians, and the legal system), measured on an 11-point scale for political distrust indicators.
method.independent_variables: Primary: concern about immigration (index). Country-level / contextual: long-term immigration country dummy, far-right party popularity/vote share, social protection expenditure, GDP per capita, unemployment, governance quality. Individual-level additional predictors: voting for far-right parties (propensity), economic satisfaction/dissatisfaction, interpersonal trust, political ideology (left-right), social capital.
method.control_variables: Demographics (age, gender, education, household income), left-right self-placement, general unhappiness/life dissatisfaction, social capital (frequency of meetings with friends), measures of governance performance and economic perceptions, and voting for government/sitting parties.
method.tools_software: HLM software (hierarchical linear modeling software) mentioned for multilevel estimation; references to standard multilevel modeling literature (e.g., Raudenbush & Bryk). Specific statistical packages beyond HLM software are not stated.

results.summary: Concern about immigration is a consistent, statistically significant predictor of political distrust in national political institutions across models, even after controlling for alternative explanations (economic dissatisfaction, interpersonal distrust, demographic factors, governance quality). The effect is stronger in countries with a long history of post-WWII immigration (interaction effect) and is only weakly amplified by measures of far-right party popularity unless combined with individual-level immigration concern. Other important predictors include economic dissatisfaction and interpersonal distrust; voting for far-right parties is also associated with higher distrust. The models explain meaningful proportions of variance at individual, country-round, and country levels.
